comments: Please put up more signs especially in the bus to ask people not to chit chat in the bus.üôè
description:
Without masks, droplets from a cough or sneeze on a moving train can spread to as far as 6 people away. 

With masks and other safe management measures, we can continue to travel safely on public transport. 

Watch this short video to find out more about the study done by @astarsg and @ltasg.

This study is part of a wider initiative by A*STAR and @temasekfoundation to study how transmission occurs in different settings, and thus improve our measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

comments: I know that people tend to remove their shoes put their feet on the edge of the bus seat which can be unhygienic for the next person who came aboard the bus to find a seat to sit down

Crowne Plaza Changi Airport is our airport hotel. Recently, three workers there got infected with COVID-19, most likely from foreign air crew who stayed there during their layover. 

So the hotel closed, and worked with @moh_singapore and CAAS to implement tighter procedures to keep the staff and guests safe. 

@cpchangiairport recently opened again. I visited them to see the changes. 

The hotel is now only open to foreign air crew, no staycations. 

It is divided into Green and Amber zones, depending on potential exposure to the virus. 

More measures were taken to ensure foreign air crew stay in their rooms, with contactless laundry and food delivery. 

Much care is taken to ensure staff working in the Amber zone wear Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), and are properly trained. 

Some 180 staff have also gone for vaccination. 

What left me the strongest impression was the kitchen and restaurant. It is a Green zone, where staff prepares the food and packs them. Across the demarcation of the restaurant is an Amber zone, where staff in full PPE collect the food to be delivered to the rooms. 

I met the kitchen staff, Ms Thulasi, who just returned to work after being infected with COVID-19. She said her symptoms were fortunately mild, and she was in very good spirits and just got her vaccination. When she was down, all her colleagues were quarantined, and all the management staff chipped in to help cook and clean the kitchen. 

There was a lot of positive spirit in this hotel despite what happened. I think that√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s why it has been voted the best airport hotel in the world.

comments: Amazed at how the situation is kept so well under control here in Singapore. What more can I say.... Proud to be a Singaporean. Thank You.
description:
Exactly one year ago, we evacuated 92 Singaporeans from Wuhan via @flyscoot TR121. A second evacuation flight followed a week later, with 174 returning home. 

In the year since, together with @singaporeair Group, we have brought home thousands of Singaporeans from all corners of the world. 

At the same time, we worked with our international partners so that foreign nationals could make their trips back. 

These operations required meticulous planning and close co-ordination, within and outside of Singapore. We are grateful for their support. 

It shows the unique Singapore spirit. We never leave our own out in the lurch. 

Today, many commercial flights are restored, and people can make their way home, go overseas to study or work. The situation is much better, and we have to continue to strive to restore our connectivity to the world.

Bus and train passenger volumes during peak hour have gone up by 11% this month, compared to before the year-end season. 

COVID-19 has made us use technology to work smarter, and demonstrated that even as more people return to office to work, the peak hour rush and crush is totally unnecessary. 

So for staff who need to go back to office, I urge employers to have them travel off-peak. 

The Public Service is taking the lead, and the MOT Family is doing our part. 

At @ltasg, officers can report to work at 7.30am or 10am, or work from home for at least 50% of the time. @motsingapore too has similar practices. 

This spreads out the load on our buses, trains and roads.  It makes rides safer and better. COVID-19 is an opportunity to shift our travelling habits. It√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s about time. 

Catch the waves of change, #traveloffpeak.

Photo credit: The Straits Times √Ç¬©√Ø¬∏¬è Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.

So for staff who need to go back to office, I urge employers to have them travel off-peak. 

The Public Service is taking the lead, and the MOT Family is doing our part. 

At @ltasg, officers can report to work at 7.30am or 10am, or work from home for at least 50% of the time. @motsingapore too has similar practices. 

This spreads out the load on our buses, trains and roads.  It makes rides safer and better. COVID-19 is an opportunity to shift our travelling habits. It√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s about time. 

Catch the waves of change, #traveloffpeak.

Photo credit: The Straits Times √Ç¬©√Ø¬∏¬è Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.

comments: üëèüëè Hope Taiwan will open up to us too! Many are looking forward to travelling to Taiwan
description:
Today, we take another step in opening our borders, this time to travellers from #Taiwan.

They have been maintaining close to zero infection rates and strong control measures, so the risk of importation is low. They will be able to enter #Singapore from 18 Dec without SHN.

We have earlier opened to Australia, Brunei, Mainland China, New Zealand and Vietnam. Some 4,000 general travellers have entered Singapore since we started unilateral opening in September, and all had tested negative for COVID-19.

Taiwan has recently classified Singapore as a low risk country and reduced the quarantine for essential and business travellers from Singapore to five days.

With the festive period, I hope the reopening arrangements will be useful for families and loved ones to reunite.

comments: Dear Minister Ong, this is definitely a good news. I am also hopeful that we will be opening up to Thailand soon. Currently on business trip at BKK and sincerely hope when I am back to SGP, I will not need to serve another long 14 days of SHN. üòÉüôè

description: The E-Bridge pre-school will finally open in Jan 21 at East Canberra (Blk 126), after a Covid-19 delay. I paid a visit over the weekend. It is very well designed, with a great facing that makes it bright a cheery in the morning. It has a full capacity of around 200, but opening with around 60, from infants to K2. This is much needed in our young estate at East Canberra. Many thanks to everyone, and especially my good friends at E-Bridge, who set this up. Check out the photos.

comments: Great and tough Decision, safety comes first!
description:
This morning, CAAS announced that the Singapore-Hong Kong Air Travel Bubble (ATB) will be launched as scheduled, with arriving passengers subject to an on-arrival test as a further precaution. 

Given the evolving situation in Hong Kong, Secretary Edward Yau and I discussed further this afternoon, and decided that it would be better to defer the launch of the ATB, by two weeks. We will review within two weeks on the new launch date and update again. 

I can fully understand the disappointment and frustration of travellers who have planned their trips. But we think it is better to defer from a public health standpoint. The airlines will be contacting the travellers individually.

This is a sober reminder that the COVID-19 virus is still with us, and even as we fight to regain our normal lives, the journey will be full of ups and downs. But we will press on and look forward to when we can safely launch the ATB.

comments: Good decision! Thanks for your courage in doing the right thing.

This is a sober reminder that the COVID-19 virus is still with us, and even as we fight to regain our normal lives, the journey will be full of ups and downs. But we will press on and look forward to when we can safely launch the ATB.

This morning, CAAS announced that the Singapore-Hong Kong Air Travel Bubble (ATB) will be launched as scheduled, with arriving passengers subject to an on-arrival test as a further precaution. 

Given the evolving situation in Hong Kong, Secretary Edward Yau and I discussed further this afternoon, and decided that it would be better to defer the launch of the ATB, by two weeks. We will review within two weeks on the new launch date and update again. 

I can fully understand the disappointment and frustration of travellers who have planned their trips. But we think it is better to defer from a public health standpoint. The airlines will be contacting the travellers individually.

This is a sober reminder that the COVID-19 virus is still with us, and even as we fight to regain our normal lives, the journey will be full of ups and downs. But we will press on and look forward to when we can safely launch the ATB.

comments: MIinister, i want to fist bump with you too üòÅ
description:
Fist bumps are the new handshakes. I often have to explain why I need to decline residents√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ invitations into their homes. But we now exchange greetings and the occasional laughs at the doorsteps. 

Many will ask me to wait while they put their masks on. I can see that everyone is coping better with all these safe measures. 

This is quiet resilience. 

#MakeSembawangSpecial

Today we announced that #Singapore will open its borders to #MainlandChina and the state of #Victoria (Australia). The latest additions join the list of places we announced earlier - rest of Australia, Brunei, New Zealand and Vietnam.

These are countries which have low COVID-19 incidence rates and strong surveillance programmes, with risk profiles similar to Singapore.

The number of visitors coming from these places are not large - 602 so far, and all have tested negative.

And we are discussing an Air Travel Bubble with Hong Kong. This is a first of its kind arrangement in the world, between two aviation hubs, for all travellers and replacing quarantine with testing. We expect it to start in Nov 2020.

All these are important moves to ready ourselves, so that when the world is ready to travel again, @changiairport will thrive and @singaporeair will soar again.

comments: Yes, Singapore will definitely succeed, sure enough. SIA will be a Great Way to Fly again, in time to come.

Next up is #Australia and #Vietnam. 

Like #Brunei and #NewZealand, Australia and Vietnam have also very successfully controlled the spread of the COVID-19 virus. We will hence lift border restrictions for visitors from Vietnam and Australia (excluding Victoria). They can apply for an Air Travel Pass (ATP), and undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival, in lieu of a SHN. 

With each step of safe opening of our borders, we start to rebuild the bridges, and resuscitate #ChangiAirport.

Visited #changiairport today. It√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s very quiet, but I saw how we cleared a group of passengers from Brunei. We lifted border restrictions for Brunei and NZ earlier this month, so once passengers from these countries are tested negative for Covid 19 they can move around Singapore freely. Also did my small part for the retailers at the airport. Love the fish skins.

description:
My new #MOT role took me to two important places in my first two days at work √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú Changi Airport and Singapore Airlines. SMS Chee Hong Tat joined me.
 
Air connectivity is a vital organ of our small island state. It connects #Singapore to the rest of the world. Being an air hub breathes oxygen into every other economic sector and helps them thrive and create more jobs.

Changi Airport, with the 126 carriers it serves, and SIA as our national flag carrier, anchor our status as a global air hub. But due to COVID-19, global aviation is still reeling in crisis.

To revive air travel in and out of Singapore, we have to find ways to allow for safe travel. It is our top and immediate priority.

To revive air travel in and out of Singapore, we have to find ways to allow for safe travel. It is our top and immediate priority.

A reason to look forward to school reopening - CCAs are restarting! But with safety rules - max 20 students per activity; within the 20, max of 5 can have closer interactions (e.g. 2v2 basketball); and modified rules such that players must be 1m apart. 

Still not quite the same, but these are extraordinary times. 

P/S: #MMA still not allowed in school.

On 10 July, all of us at MOE were dismayed when we learnt that at Jurong West Secondary School, a student who caught the COVID-19 virus at home, had infected another classmate. This would have been our first recorded COVID-19 infection in school, despite all our precautionary measures.
 
To our relief, TTSH and MOH have clarified that it was a case of erroneous reporting by the testing laboratory. The student, plus the rest of the contacts, were tested to be negative. 
 
Notwithstanding the mistake, I have been very comforted that school attendance rates at Jurong West have maintained at over 90%. Students, parents and teachers have adapted well to all our precautionary measures √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú calmly and with resolve to minimise disruptions to learning. 
 
We will not let up. Schools will take all necessary measures to keep schools safe, and allow learning to go on as much as possible. We are still in the process of adjusting to a stable new normal. Thanks to all parents, students and teachers for their understanding and effort.

(√∞≈∏‚Äú¬∑ credit: Google Street View)

On 10 July, all of us at MOE were dismayed when we learnt that at Jurong West Secondary School, a student who caught the COVID-19 virus at home, had infected another classmate. This would have been our first recorded COVID-19 infection in school, despite all our precautionary measures.
 
To our relief, TTSH and MOH have clarified that it was a case of erroneous reporting by the testing laboratory. The student, plus the rest of the contacts, were tested to be negative. 
 
Notwithstanding the mistake, I have been very comforted that school attendance rates at Jurong West have maintained at over 90%. Students, parents and teachers have adapted well to all our precautionary measures √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú calmly and with resolve to minimise disruptions to learning. 
 
We will not let up. Schools will take all necessary measures to keep schools safe, and allow learning to go on as much as possible. We are still in the process of adjusting to a stable new normal. Thanks to all parents, students and teachers for their understanding and effort.

(√∞≈∏‚Äú¬∑ credit: Google Street View)

description:
Students from all levels returned to school today. Visited Ngee Ann Secondary School this morning to see how they were coping with the full student population back in school. Students and teachers are familiar with the safe management measures by now. 
Upper and lower secondary students take designated routes to their classrooms when they enter the school, so no overcrowding. 
Teachers continue to conscientiously check with students if they or their household members are unwell. Question screening remains a very important step in helping us quickly identify potential cases and prevent any clusters in schools. 
With all students back now, it's even more important that all of us practise social responsibility to continue keeping our schools a safe place.

With all students back now, it's even more important that all of us practise social responsibility to continue keeping our schools a safe place.

You all heard the news: Phase 2 of re-opening starts this Friday, 19 June.

It is a significant step. Most activities will resume, except certain larger scale ones with close interaction activities, that have potential to be mass spreading events. Social gatherings should have a maximum of five people. 
All the things we miss - sitting in coffeeshops or restaurants, bubble tea, tuition and enrichment classes, meeting up with boyfriends or girlfriends, can all resume. 
It took us a lot of sacrifice to get here, after a fairly long circuit breaker period, and a careful Phase 1 opening. But during this time, all of us co-operated, and we suppressed the virus transmission. 
From here, it is up to us again. We will all take care of our personal hygiene, adopt necessary precautionary measures, look out for one another. That way, we keep the virus under control in Phase 2. While we are all eager to meet up with friends and socialise, we will do so safely. No need to all rush out on Friday - everywhere will be full. Can take our time a bit, and ease into our social activities again. My daughter already told me I must wait for my Father√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s Day dinner. 
Schools will continue with our weekly rotation plan, and comprehensive safe management measures. We will bring all students back daily from 29 June. MOE will give more details soon.

Have fun but stay safe! (Photo taken before COVID-19.)

description:
Yesterday was the first day of distribution of the improved reusable mask. Happy to see that at Sembawang, queues were orderly, centres were not crowded, good distancing measures were observed, and residents appreciated the masks distribution. 
Physical collection centres are available until 1 June, after which residents have until 14 June to collect their masks from designated CCs / RCs / vending machines. 
Visit https://www.maskgowhere.gov.sg to get more information, or to check the availability of masks in the vending machines.

It was not too long ago when I lit the flame for the 2020 National School Games. Since then, MOE had to make the painful decision to cancel the games, due to COVID-19.  Many students have trained very hard for the games, and are naturally disappointed, even devastated. 
This turn of events has been hard on our young ones, but you are also not alone.  Sports has been a major casualty of COVID-19. Tens of thousands of athletes have trained for the Olympics, to peak at the right time, only to see it postponed, with a total cancellation not ruled out. UEFA Euro 2020 football also postponed. Wimbledon is cancelled. Liverpool FC is two wins away from their first championship in 30 years, and is still unsure if the league can resume. 
But the most important reason you can take this in your stride is that you are young and have a long journey ahead, be it in studies or sports. If you are a Junior or Senior, C or B Div athlete, you have more opportunities to train, participate and compete. If you are in the A Div and graduating this year, cherish the run that you have had. 
And everyone should remember this √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú once an athlete, always an athlete. Because you will bring with you the enduring values and spirit that sports represent √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú hard work, diligence, teamwork, friendship, and resilience. These are the same values that will help you get over the current disappointment, and overcome various setbacks and challenges in life. 
So I know you will bounce back from this disappointment. In the meantime, set up that friendly match when COVID-19 is over.

description:
It was not too long ago when I lit the flame for the 2020 National School Games. Since then, MOE had to make the painful decision to cancel the games, due to COVID-19.  Many students have trained very hard for the games, and are naturally disappointed, even devastated. 
This turn of events has been hard on our young ones, but you are also not alone.  Sports has been a major casualty of COVID-19. Tens of thousands of athletes have trained for the Olympics, to peak at the right time, only to see it postponed, with a total cancellation not ruled out. UEFA Euro 2020 football also postponed. Wimbledon is cancelled. Liverpool FC is two wins away from their first championship in 30 years, and is still unsure if the league can resume. 
But the most important reason you can take this in your stride is that you are young and have a long journey ahead, be it in studies or sports. If you are a Junior or Senior, C or B Div athlete, you have more opportunities to train, participate and compete. If you are in the A Div and graduating this year, cherish the run that you have had. 
And everyone should remember this √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú once an athlete, always an athlete. Because you will bring with you the enduring values and spirit that sports represent √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú hard work, diligence, teamwork, friendship, and resilience. These are the same values that will help you get over the current disappointment, and overcome various setbacks and challenges in life. 
So I know you will bounce back from this disappointment. In the meantime, set up that friendly match when COVID-19 is over.

comments: Speaking as a fellow Liverpool fan, winning isn‚Äôt everything . It‚Äôs the journey of discovering oneself, overcoming all the hurdles life throws at you and coming out stronger. Yes, these generation of kids are battle hardened to say the least. They will bounce back from this setback and come out stronger. We walk with them anyday...YNWA YNWA YNWA.

comments: Gone through the same disappointment for 2004 Olympics. Was training towards what would probably be my only shot at Olympics but 2 years before the games. As we exit from the Circuit Breaker from 2 Jun, we will embark on a roadmap to the eventual full opening of schools. 
But the first step, on 2 Jun, should be a cautious one, to re-open schools safely. We will progressively bring back students to schools and Institutes of Higher Learning. 
How?

First, we will prioritise the return of those who need a higher level of care, like students in Special Education schools, as well as graduating cohorts who needs to prepare for national exams. 
Second, for students not in graduating cohorts, we will have a weekly rotation system so that different levels of students take turns to come to school and to do HBL. So for primary school, it will be P4 and P5 coming back to school and P1, P2, P3 doing HBL in week 1, and the reverse in Week 2. P6s will come back every day.

We aim to gradually have all students fully back in school after two cycles of weekly rotation, or four weeks.

We will also continue to support high needs students and children of parents who need to work and cannot find alternate childcare arrangement, and allow them to come to school on their HBL week. 
Many students will be excited to return to school. Parents may be looking forward to school opening too, especially if they have to return to work. But I am sure parents are also worried about their children√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s safety. Rest assured that we will take whatever precautions we can to ensure the well-being of all students and staff. 
Third, we will implement a stringent safe management system, including screening of anyone that comes into schools, good hygiene habits, group separation to prevent inter-mingling of students from different classes, and safe distancing which include the wearing masks/face shields by teachers and students. 
COVID-19 will be with us for some time. Let us take the necessary steps and precautions, to regain our lives as much as possible.

description:
As we exit from the Circuit Breaker from 2 Jun, we will embark on a roadmap to the eventual full opening of schools. 
But the first step, on 2 Jun, should be a cautious one, to re-open schools safely. We will progressively bring back students to schools and Institutes of Higher Learning. 
How?

First, we will prioritise the return of those who need a higher level of care, like students in Special Education schools, as well as graduating cohorts who needs to prepare for national exams. 
Second, for students not in graduating cohorts, we will have a weekly rotation system so that different levels of students take turns to come to school and to do HBL. So for primary school, it will be P4 and P5 coming back to school and P1, P2, P3 doing HBL in week 1, and the reverse in Week 2. P6s will come back every day.

We aim to gradually have all students fully back in school after two cycles of weekly rotation, or four weeks.

We will also continue to support high needs students and children of parents who need to work and cannot find alternate childcare arrangement, and allow them to come to school on their HBL week. 
Many students will be excited to return to school. Parents may be looking forward to school opening too, especially if they have to return to work. But I am sure parents are also worried about their children√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s safety. Rest assured that we will take whatever precautions we can to ensure the well-being of all students and staff. 
Third, we will implement a stringent safe management system, including screening of anyone that comes into schools, good hygiene habits, group separation to prevent inter-mingling of students from different classes, and safe distancing which include the wearing masks/face shields by teachers and students. 
COVID-19 will be with us for some time. Let us take the necessary steps and precautions, to regain our lives as much as possible.

Visited Temasek Poly yesterday, one of the five sites where pre-school staff were undergoing their COVID-19 tests, in preparation for re-opening of schools.  Important precaution, because pre-school staff can come into very close contact with the students. I am so impressed by the pre-school staff, so calm and co-operative with all the doctors and nurses. When I used the loudhailer and asked them how was the test, many showed me √∞≈∏‚Äò¬ç

Several final year poly students have expressed to me their disappointment that there will be no graduating ceremonies because of COVID-19. 
I can fully understand. This is an important milestone for you and your parents. But unfortunately, it is currently not safe to hold ceremonies. We don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t want to trigger a cluster of infections. Then a happy occasion will become a tragedy. 
I never attended any of my graduation ceremonies. I was lucky to receive overseas scholarships for my Bachelor√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s and later my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s degrees. When I finished my undergraduate studies, I was immediately summoned to return to Singapore to serve my bond. Years later, when I finished my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s, I rushed back because our first baby was going to pop anytime. So again I missed my graduation. 
The first time I donned a graduation gown was in 2015, after I became Minister for Education, and attended NUS√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ Commencement ceremony as guest-of-honour. 
Today, I am just glad I had a good education and can put what I have learned to good use.  I have never lamented not having attended my graduation ceremonies. I missed them for reasons more important than attending them. 
In a similar vein, after 23 years of marriage, my wife and I hardly remember our wedding dinner or ceremony, but we remember the times we spent together and bringing up our children.

If you are in your final year, trust me, years from now, you will not miss the graduation ceremony. You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

comments: A graduation ceremony is every parents hope and students proud moment being a celebration of the fruit of their hard work and effort.  It can be postponed till a later date when the situation gets better and not merely cancel it without having a deeper thought and effort to make things work to its best for all.
description:
Several final year poly students have expressed to me their disappointment that there will be no graduating ceremonies because of COVID-19. 
I can fully understand. This is an important milestone for you and your parents. But unfortunately, it is currently not safe to hold ceremonies. We don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t want to trigger a cluster of infections. Then a happy occasion will become a tragedy. 
I never attended any of my graduation ceremonies. I was lucky to receive overseas scholarships for my Bachelor√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s and later my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s degrees. When I finished my undergraduate studies, I was immediately summoned to return to Singapore to serve my bond. Years later, when I finished my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s, I rushed back because our first baby was going to pop anytime. So again I missed my graduation. 
The first time I donned a graduation gown was in 2015, after I became Minister for Education, and attended NUS√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ Commencement ceremony as guest-of-honour. 
Today, I am just glad I had a good education and can put what I have learned to good use.  I have never lamented not having attended my graduation ceremonies. I missed them for reasons more important than attending them. 
In a similar vein, after 23 years of marriage, my wife and I hardly remember our wedding dinner or ceremony, but we remember the times we spent together and bringing up our children.

If you are in your final year, trust me, years from now, you will not miss the graduation ceremony. You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

comments: As a graduating student myself, I fully understand your stand and agree that it would be for the best that ceremonies are not held. I think students need a reason to celebrate and showcase their achievements, so maybe we can explore more ways to give them the fame they need. Personally, I have no problem with the cancellation of the graduation ceremony, because I strongly believe that the friends I‚Äôve gained, the lessons i‚Äôve learnt and the knowledge and experiences I‚Äôve equipped myself with through school, are my greatest takeaways. And that‚Äôs enough for me. ‚ù§Ô∏è Stay safe everyone, and thanks Minister for the post.

comments: hi mr ong, ur post is really well said. however, u cant assume all graduates are just like u. i think we are all different enough to find different values in everything. some of us might think that the ceremony is an important milestone and memory to have at this age. i dont think its very good to assume and have people to trust u, that years from now they will not miss the ceremony... like u said, u didnt attend the ceremony, maybe we could consider it as a factor to why this is of minimal sentiment value to u.all in all, i do get ur intention of this post which is to raise awareness to graduates by giving them an explanation to the cancellation and providing them a fresh point of view from ur side. however, i think the graduates all know by now the reason for the cancellation and they do not need another announcement and reminder that the virus is still out there. it is just the matter of a decision to be made for a postponement instead.nonetheless, we are all grateful for u to serve as our minister of education and i really do appreciate ur concern for graduates through this post! do keep urself safe from the virus as well! :)

You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

comments: Many thanks for speaking on this matter Minister. Appreciate you showing your concern towards this matter. Just want to let you and your team know that you guys are doing a great job! :)

comments: To poly or Uni grads, I hear you. It can be genuinely heartbreaking to graduate without your loved ones there to bear witness. However, these measures are meant to keep you and your loved ones safe. After all, isn't that what's most important?

comments: Mr Ong, on my first day of Poly, i remember walking into school, and saw the sign pointing to the graduation Ceremonies. I saw all my graduating seniors in robes with flowers and i thought to myself, hey that could absolutely be me one day. This thought was triggered again when I received my Freshmen Scholarship at the same ceremony as one of the diplomas. Hence when it was announced that graduation Ceremonies would be cancelled, it severely guttered many of us. We worked our butts off to get to this point. I'd like to humbly ask you to consider holding graduation Ceremonies for the graduating class of 2020 when the outbreak stabilizes

comments: Nah man, I will miss not having a graduation ceremony. I worked so hard just to get to where I am. I took the long way. From ITE to Poly. Or next April, with the next batch. I cannot relate to your experiences.

description:
Several final year poly students have expressed to me their disappointment that there will be no graduating ceremonies because of COVID-19. 
I can fully understand. This is an important milestone for you and your parents. But unfortunately, it is currently not safe to hold ceremonies. We don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t want to trigger a cluster of infections. Then a happy occasion will become a tragedy. 
I never attended any of my graduation ceremonies. I was lucky to receive overseas scholarships for my Bachelor√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s and later my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s degrees. When I finished my undergraduate studies, I was immediately summoned to return to Singapore to serve my bond. Years later, when I finished my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s, I rushed back because our first baby was going to pop anytime. So again I missed my graduation. 
The first time I donned a graduation gown was in 2015, after I became Minister for Education, and attended NUS√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ Commencement ceremony as guest-of-honour. 
Today, I am just glad I had a good education and can put what I have learned to good use.  I have never lamented not having attended my graduation ceremonies. I missed them for reasons more important than attending them. 
In a similar vein, after 23 years of marriage, my wife and I hardly remember our wedding dinner or ceremony, but we remember the times we spent together and bringing up our children.

If you are in your final year, trust me, years from now, you will not miss the graduation ceremony. You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

comments: Im sorry Minister Ong, but I disagree. Many people find graduation a very important ceremony. For one to voluntarily not have graduation is different from 36 THOUSAND Students forced to not have a graduation. As a graduate if 2020, I think you have the wrong mindset. We have been asking to POSTPONE graduation because we know and understand AND are concerned about the safety of Singaporeans during this period. And we understand the measures are necessary to keep Singaporeans Safe. If you read the petition, you will see that. We are not a bunch of graduates WHINING about not having our graduation. But we are asking for your support to help us to POSTPONE graduation. Put yourself in the positions of graduates, their parents and the lecturers who have taught us over 3-4 years. The accomplishments. And the rest of Singaporeans, look, put yourselves in our position. If you were to have your graduation cancelled how would you feel as a parent or even as a student? Dont misunderstand us. We are not looking to have it DURING covid-19. But AFTER covid-19. To many of us, it really does not matter when we have it. Just as long as we have it when it is safe to celebrate with the nation. That is all, stay safe Minister Ong and all Singaporeans.

description:
Several final year poly students have expressed to me their disappointment that there will be no graduating ceremonies because of COVID-19. 
I can fully understand. This is an important milestone for you and your parents. But unfortunately, it is currently not safe to hold ceremonies. We don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t want to trigger a cluster of infections. Then a happy occasion will become a tragedy. 
I never attended any of my graduation ceremonies. I was lucky to receive overseas scholarships for my Bachelor√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s and later my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s degrees. When I finished my undergraduate studies, I was immediately summoned to return to Singapore to serve my bond. Years later, when I finished my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s, I rushed back because our first baby was going to pop anytime. So again I missed my graduation. 
The first time I donned a graduation gown was in 2015, after I became Minister for Education, and attended NUS√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ Commencement ceremony as guest-of-honour. 
Today, I am just glad I had a good education and can put what I have learned to good use.  I have never lamented not having attended my graduation ceremonies. I missed them for reasons more important than attending them. 
In a similar vein, after 23 years of marriage, my wife and I hardly remember our wedding dinner or ceremony, but we remember the times we spent together and bringing up our children.

If you are in your final year, trust me, years from now, you will not miss the graduation ceremony. You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

We are making history just by staying home and staying alive and well through whether a cancelled/postponed graduation/wedding ceremony etc just to #stayhomeforsg as PM and DPM exhort #sgunited! May God bless you and family in this Easter Sunday!
description:
Several final year poly students have expressed to me their disappointment that there will be no graduating ceremonies because of COVID-19. 
I can fully understand. This is an important milestone for you and your parents. But unfortunately, it is currently not safe to hold ceremonies. We don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t want to trigger a cluster of infections. Then a happy occasion will become a tragedy. 
I never attended any of my graduation ceremonies. I was lucky to receive overseas scholarships for my Bachelor√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s and later my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s degrees. When I finished my undergraduate studies, I was immediately summoned to return to Singapore to serve my bond. Years later, when I finished my Master√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s, I rushed back because our first baby was going to pop anytime. So again I missed my graduation. 
The first time I donned a graduation gown was in 2015, after I became Minister for Education, and attended NUS√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ Commencement ceremony as guest-of-honour. 
Today, I am just glad I had a good education and can put what I have learned to good use.  I have never lamented not having attended my graduation ceremonies. I missed them for reasons more important than attending them. 
In a similar vein, after 23 years of marriage, my wife and I hardly remember our wedding dinner or ceremony, but we remember the times we spent together and bringing up our children.

If you are in your final year, trust me, years from now, you will not miss the graduation ceremony. You will remember that you graduated in an extraordinary year in history, where the human spirit was put to the most stringent of tests, and kindness and love in our communities helped us pull through. 
But do mark the occasion at home with your loved ones. Take a nice picture and have a nice meal with your family. But I am sure you can come up with much better ideas to celebrate the occasion than mine. 
Congratulations! #sgunited #stayhomeforsg

comments: Thank you for Sharing your story .

comments: Hi Minister Ong,Please do reconsider giving parents the option to keep kids at home.  It really doesn‚Äôt make sense to on one hand,  call for draconian safe distancing measures and ironically, at the same time allow school to continue to run as normal albeit with measures and precaution.  It‚Äôs the biggest mass gathering in sgp right now.  Truth is, classes itself have at least 30/40 pax, and 300 at the cohort level.  It is almost impossible to maintain measures at all times.  Just drop by any school at any given day and have look at the lack of safe distancing at drop -offs and pick-ups as a case in point.  Kids may be less susceptible to the virus but are not entirely immune too.  They may also he asymptomatic carriers that go on to pass these to family members or others within their community.  Yes, it may not be inconvenient for working parents or parents of lower income brackets to miss work.  So pls make it optional.  Having schools open (even with caution) lends  little credibility to your argument.  There are always ways to tweak around a situation.  Pls look into it.  Thank you!

description:
This is the √¢‚Ç¨≈ìhealth certificate√¢‚Ç¨¬ù that may come in handy when you travel next time.

COVID-19 test results, and soon, your vaccination status, may become very relevant information at the check-in and immigration counters for cross border travel. But they will need to be easily verifiable.

Airlines are foreseeing this. So @singaporeair is working with International Air Transport Association (#IATA), and #Affinidi, a local technology company founded by @temasekseen, to start a trial on digital verification for COVID-19 tests and soon, vaccinations.

Accredited labs will issue a health certificate - a QR code on mobile or printed on paper - to passengers, to be scanned and verified easily and securely by airlines and immigration officers using an app.

Hopefully, with the support of IATA, various airlines and authorities around the world, this can become the norm, and replace the yellow book.

I applaud the industry√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s initiative. @motsingapore and #CAAS will support this as much as we can, to make this a regional or international practice. We are #OneAviation team. 

Photo credit: Affinidi
[The verifier app developed by Affinidi (foreground) lets airline staff and ICA officials easily scan QR codes to verify COVID-19 test results. The QR code in the background is stored on a separate app developed by International SOS.]

Phase 3 announced, vaccines in transit. Steps will also be taken, to allow limited, safe, face-to-face international business meetings.

Zoom cannot replace some face-to-face business meetings, e.g. signing agreements, or discussing with key teams, getting to know key partners in person.

Connect@Changi, will provide the first of its kind facility to enable such meetings to be carried out safely.

This is a national resilience project, led by @temasekseen, @surbanajurong, @changiairport, Ascott and SingEx.

This video explains how it is done.
